pages.text: Huskies have three genes that affect how they look. These are the B Locus, S Locus, and W Locus. The B Locus determines whether a dog is black or red, while the S Locus determines whether the dog is solid colored or has a saddle-like marking. The W Locus can create solid white fur over the B and S Locus.

The B Locus has two potential alleles, the dominant 'B' and the recessive 'b'. The 'B' allele creates black coloration, while the 'b' allele creates red coloration. Dogs with one copy of 'b' will carry the red trait and may pass it on to pups, providing the potential for red pups depending on the other parent. Dogs with two copies of 'b' will always create either red carriers or red puppies.
pages.title: B Locus

pages.text: The S Locus has two potential alleles, the dominant 'S' and the recessive 's'. The 'S' allele creates a saddle-like marking, while the 's' allele creates a solid pattern. Dogs with one copy of 's' will carry the solid trait and may pass it on to pups, providing the potential for solid pups depending on the other parent. Dogs with two copies of 's' will always create either solid carriers or solid puppies.
pages.title: S Locus

pages.text: The W Locus has two potential alleles, the dominant 'W' and recessive 'w'. The 'W' allele creates the standard white markings of a husky, while the 'w' creates a pure white coat. Dogs with one copy of 'w' will carry the white fur trait and may pass it on to pups, providing the potential for white pups depending on the other parent. Dogs with two copies of 'w' will always create either white carriers or white puppies.
pages.title: W Locus
